segments.text: Tell me something about your family situation, where you lived in 1975.
I live in Vietnam, in Saigon, the main city.
And practically the whole family is in the military, my dad and my uncles and all that.
And my mom, she was a banker in Vietnam.
And we were still going to school, to elementary school in 75.
So you were there in Saigon during the fall?
Uh-huh.
We were still in there.
In fact, the whole family, nobody was out of town or anything.
Everybody was at home by that time.
Can you tell me about the final few days there in Saigon?
Well, it was pretty crazy.
Everybody's going berserk because they know it's going to,
you know, this country's going to fall and fail, you know.
And basically everybody's running around trying to look for a place so that they could escape, and the main one was just at the U.S. Embassy.
That's where the main place, because at the last minute, there were at least a couple of helicopters
flying back and forth trying to take out the Americans that are still there.
And all these people trying to get in and trying to jump in, trying to escape with them.
And that's one way.
And the other way is everybody went out to the port to go on the ship that was either an oil tanker or a
or an American Navy ship that were there for a long time.
And they would go and they would be gone, taken away to wherever the boat was.
And so everybody was just crowded up there trying to get in.
It was real hectic.
A lot of vandalized people shopped in stores, getting all the windows broken, all the stuff stolen.
But they didn't care because
You know, they'd rather have freedom more than living with the communists and all that.
And they were worried about their family.
And the young people, they really wanted to go.
And some, you know, they stayed back.
Some, they decided that if there was no way, they'd probably stay back and try to live through it.
Did you see any troops?

When I was out in the street, there wasn't any troop maneuvering at all, but a couple nights before the final took over, we were in a church, and I could see that there were military tanks and all that moving down the street, and I didn't know which side it was on, but I'm pretty sure that...
I'm pretty sure that it was the South moving backward, trying to pull back.
And also, behind the tank, there were a whole bunch of soldiers just running back.
In fact, everybody from the South Vietnamese army was just pulling back and taking off their clothes so that they could hide their identity.
so that just in case if the colonists come in, they won't know that he was in the army, you know, in the forces and all that.
And after that was gone, you know, you would see a whole bunch of bum people where they would go and pick up the stuff that the soldier had dropped, you know, like guns and clothes or maybe...
If the soldiers, they didn't care what they drop off.
They drop off their ID and wallets and all that.
So they had some money.
So those bum people or poor people, they would go and try to look for money or cigarettes, you know, a few cigarettes to smoke and all that.
And some food like, you know, candies or something like that.
Try to pick up whatever's left.
What did your family do?
Did you all try to leave through the embassy?
My mom and my dad took three of us to the embassy on our car.
And when we got there, it was so crowded that we couldn't barely move the car.
So my dad knew that we had no chance of getting in.
So because there were people all over the place.
They were climbing on fences and all that.
And so we decided to go back home.

And basically, our whole family just stayed at home because my grandmother, at that time, she wanted everybody to be together, especially in our house, so that she know where everybody is and she know that nobody's going to be missing and all that.
Because during the hectic, you want to keep your family together so that you won't have any trouble finding them.
And when we went home after we went to the embassy,
My grandma told us that why don't we go to the church and stay there a couple nights just in case if the communists come in early and they would take my dad away so fast.
So in other words, we went to the churches.
you know, just to hide out for a couple of days.
And we went there.
But otherwise, we didn't think of going to the port or anything like that.
We thought that the embassy was our last choice.
And it wasn't open, so we thought everybody just stayed home.
And in fact,
One night, the night that we were supposed to go to the church, we had dinner, and it was just a normal, regular old family dinner.
Of course, a lot of people in my family, they were planning.
They were thinking real hard trying to find a way to escape.
Somehow, it was real quiet and all that.
They couldn't think of the port.
And afterward, when we got over here, my mom was real mad.
Because if we would have thought of going to the port, then the whole family could have gone together instead of going one by one over.
Basically, the port was the main thing.
A lot of Vietnamese people that wanted to get out got out by the port at the last minute before the communists came in.
In fact, when the communists came in, there was this one ship that had loaded a whole bunch of people.
They took off shore just in time before the communists came in.
And those people got out.
And the people that were still left on the shore, they were so unhappy.
So they didn't know what to do.
So they would just go home.
And they said, well, that's it.
That's the last chance we could leave.
So what did your family do immediately after the fall, when the communists were in?
After the fall, we
We went on our daily lives, but of course, during that time, I think around at least two or three, two weeks, there wasn't any work.
You know, my mom didn't go to work.
My dad didn't go to work.
Nobody went to work.
In fact, everybody stayed at home.
And we practically just stayed inside the house so that, you know, so that just to keep out of trouble.
And in fact, I'm pretty sure that all the other families are too, you know.
So the street was just deserted and all that.
But basically, we just went on doing our daily life stuff and all that except for going to work.
And, you know,
We all knew, my mom and my grandmother, you know, they all knew that one day my dad's going to get taken.
So, in fact, in other words, you know, we just stayed at the house just waiting for them to, for the communist to knock on the door, you know.
That's all.
And, you know, we minded our own business.
There wasn't, we didn't visit any friends.
We didn't have any visitor or anything like that at all.
It was just like a family only in one house and all that.
So what finally happened with your father?
Well, after that two weeks, business started going.
You know, people starting to open their shops and going to work and all that.
The communist, they started to come to our house a couple of times, you know, stay around two or three hours just going in, acting real friendly, you know, talking to my dad and all that.
And there were like around five of them.
They came in wearing their uniform, and they drove up by, you know, they used a jeep to drive to our house, and they went in, and when they came in,
My dad and my mom stayed out and talked to them, but my mom told us to go inside to the bedroom and stay in there.
But I was so curious, and my sister was so curious, too, so we would...
sneak out, you know, just take a little peek and hear what they're saying and all that.
And basically it was a real friendly conversation asking, you know, how it is and all that.
And then after that, and then after that, uh, they,
They come back a couple of days, going back, talking to my dad and all that.
And then at the last meeting that they had, the same five guys that came a whole bunch of time, they came and they just took him away.
And my mom, she knew that the first meeting that they had, she knew that a couple more times and he's going to be taken away.
So she packed his clothes and gave him some packed medicine for him.
In fact, he had luggages already packed for him to be ready if they should take him away.
There wouldn't be any frantic of taking his clothes and just dumping them in, you know.
It was all ready there.
And the thing was just we were just waiting for them, you know, when are they going to take him away.
And the last time they came, they took him away.
And...

That was when, on that same day, they wanted all of the people that were involved in the Army to meet at an elementary school so that they could, you know, they say that they could have a meeting and all that, but actually it wasn't a meeting.
It was for them to be taken away to a concentration camp.
So your father was taken away to this concentration camp?
Mm-hmm.
Where was it?
Nobody knew.
All the other families have their husband or brothers or son taken away, but they didn't know where.
They were gone because when they started to loading people up, they told them not to follow.
They told them that just say goodbye and go home and don't follow us.

you know when when they get situated you know they'll they'll get some information about it but they were just saying that but a lot of people they didn't know it so they believed it so a lot of people were real happy about it and they just went home and didn't follow but you know my mom she knew that
that it was going to be a long time before she would get the first letter from my dad.
And so they took him away, and for I think around half a year or something like that,
There was just no news.
I mean, just no news.
My mom would not know where my dad was or where he's at or how he's doing because they would not tell you anything.
And a lot of wives were starting to get panic.
They were starting to panic.
They said,
They kept on going to the personnel office.
It's kind of like a headquarter for a particular region.
And they would come in, they would complain, they would say, how come you said that you would give us some news and now you're not going to and all that.
And they would make up some excuse that there's some trouble or...

or they or they might have gotten lost or something like that and they would make up like they would be on the same boat as we are they don't know uh what where they are or you know where they're at or you know or those things you know so those wives they were getting pretty restless and all that
So they thought, you know, a lot of people said, oh, no, my husband's probably dead or something, because you don't know if he might have died on the way there or he might die from them being killed.
And a lot of people thought that those the communists would take them on the bus so that they would take them out in the countryside and would execute them all.
That's what they thought.
There were a lot of, you know, a lot of.
rumors of what was gonna happen to those men that were taken away.
And so everybody was just really crazy, going crazy.
And finally,
A couple weeks later, finally, they would get their husband's letter and all that.
My dad sent one to us, and he wrote it to us, and he told us that he doesn't know where he's at.
He said that it is somewhere out in the country.
with farming and all that.
And he said that they're living in a shed that's made out of trees, made out of leaves and all that.
And he said that he had no idea where it is.
And he said that on the trip, it took very long.
And they did not drop all of the people that were taken in the same place.
dropped one truck to this place and the other truck to the other place.
In other words, they spread them all out in the countryside.
And he said that he doesn't know where he's at.
And he just told us that he's all right and all that.
And basically what he did was he wrote the letters and he would tell them

our address and they would mail it to him so in other words if after he writes it they would check it they would read it and check if he would you know tell them tell tell my mom anything any clue or anything but and so if whenever if my dad would say something wrong what they would do is they would get some glue and they would
remove that whole sentence out so that my mom would not know, you know, like that.
So after we were real happy to receive his letter, you know, that's better than nothing because now we know that, you know, he's still alive and all that.
And he said he was well.
And so we took his word.
And then after those letters, the wives would come back and ask those guys again, the personnel, that how...

how they supposed to send letters to them if they wanted to and so what they say is they would tell them to bring it to them so that they will mail it so in other words you have to go through them so that they would proofread it and erase whatever they you write that is wrong that is unacceptable and then they mail it to you know to to whoever that you want it to be mailed so what did your family do
plan to do now that your father was gone?
Well, after my dad was taken, well, before my dad was taken, my...
My mom and the whole family planned what are we going to do after my dad was going to be gone.
And in fact, we had a lot of discussion about it.
And my mom, she was planning to stay back.
And she was planning for us three, two of my sister and I, and my aunt to escape.
And she would stay back and take care and wait for my dad.
My dad, you know?
How long did y'all think he was going to be held?
We thought that he was going to be held for a real short time.
For the soldiers, they would be held at least one or two years.
But for him, since he is an officer, my mom and everybody else thought that he would be held around five years.
And so she thought that if she would have waited, it would still be fine, because five years is really short.
And by that time, when he comes out, then both of them could escape together.
So we agreed on that.
But then my dad wanted my mom to go with us because he felt that my aunt was not old enough to take control of us because my aunt at that time, she was only 13.
So she was pretty young also.
So he wanted...
a mature adult to be with us so that we would get through once we escaped.
So my dad convinced my mom to go.
So my mom said that, okay, she'll go.
And if she goes, my grandmother stayed back and helped my dad out.
And then when he comes out, then they both will leave.
And so that was the final decision.
So then my mom and us three and my aunt would leave.
And they would say five years later, my dad and my grandparents would go together.
And so we would leave.
And it took us a year to plan the escape, to buy boats and how many people are going to go, how much money we're supposed to pay for the boat and how many days and all that.
So your mother was doing all of this in secret?
Yes.
She was doing all this with the other people that were planning to go with us.
And the other people were basically just real close relatives.
Two of my uncles went with us, and he was...
Two of my uncles, which they are on my dad's side, went with us and my mom's best friend and her three kids.
Otherwise, we planned an escape that everybody would know each other.
Everybody was friendly so that there would not be any argument.
And there would not be any argument on what to do and all that.
And so they planned secretly.
They would plan late at night.
And my mom, she would go down to the coast
compromise with the fishermen to sell one of their boats to us.
Because back then, if you were a fisherman, you basically had around at least three ships, three boats or even more.

to for you to fish and so they they would sell us one but they would give us a really high price for it that that you know that it's just unbelievable but you just have to try to convince them that you know that that's all the money you have but basically what they wanted to do was they wanted you to give them all the money that you have because
They were thinking that since you're going to be leaving, you're going to make it so that when you come over there, you're going to make more money.
So why should you keep the Vietnamese money when you can give it to them?
That's basically why the cost was so high.
So y'all finally did get a boat.
We finally got a boat, and it was a very small boat.
Twenty-four people went.
There were four men, which three of them were my uncles, and one of them was their best friend.
Two of my uncles, which were on my dad's side, were in the Navy with their best friend.
So they knew how to operate a boat.
They knew how to navigate.
They knew which direction to go and all that.
So we didn't have any trouble in that situation because we knew that all we had to do was just get a boat, escape so that nobody knew,

and to get out in the open water and after that we knew that we would we would make it because uh we had three guys that are experienced in it and so uh we we planned and uh one night my mom told us to you know pack uh pack up and uh
Well, the night before, actually.
The night before, she told us that, you know, go to sleep early because you're going to be waking up real early in the morning around 4 or 3 or 4, and we're going to go somewhere.
So she didn't actually tell us where we were going.
And so we thought it was real strange that, you know, why would we need to wake up so early?
And so when we woke up at 3, three of us, my mom and one of my aunts, went to,

take a taxi, kind of like a minibus, and we would go to the bus station, and the bus station would take us out in the country where the port was, and at the port, we would not go 24 people at a time, we would go like six people per group, so that all the group would be separately, but then at one certain time,

time at a certain place everybody would meet and then they would we would all go to a canoe and we would roll to the main boat that we were gonna escape and then then we had to stay there a couple nights because uh in the boat yes in the boat uh under the fishing compartment because uh
for one thing, the reason why we had to stay down there because the patrol boat would get suspicious if they would see so many people on the boat.
So in other words, only the four men stayed up pretending that they were fishermen.

And also, the reason why we stayed, because the owner that sold us the boat told us that he was going to help us get out into the open water because he knows which route to take so that we would see less of the patrol headquarters and all that.
But bad for us is his boat caught in a low tide, and...
he was caught, you know, to the bottom.
And so his boat couldn't move, so he had to wait until the tide come back, you know, the high tide to come back in.
And so we had to stay down there for two whole nights, just staying down there, staying real quiet.
And at that time, it was the scariest moment for us because we were really an easy target for them to caught.
I mean, if they catch us, they would see, they would caught us red-handed.
And another thing that was the main thing was during the year that they were planning,
My mom told us to go swimming in a swimming pool because in Vietnam we have open door swimming pool.
And the reason why we wanted to do that is because the people in the country region
they were all dark skinned because they worked out in the farm and they had really, their skin is really dark and they have a dark complexion.

So that's why my mom wanted us to go down, to go to swim every day so that we would soak in the sun so that we would have a dark complexion so that they would not know that we, that they would not, the people would not know
that we were from the city and coming down.
So they thought that we would be one of the people that been here, that been in the country.
So we did that.
We all had dark skin, dark complexion.
And so we just went.
We waited two nights for them.
And then after that, the next day, they took us out to the open water and went.
Once we got out there, we didn't have any trouble.
We just got out there.
There was no stop, you know, no stop to stop or anything, no patrol boats or anything.
So once we got out there, they just told us, okay, you're on your own.
Good luck.
you know, hope you good luck and all that.
And so they waved us goodbye.
Yeah, to the fishermen.
They waved us goodbye and all that.
And they went their own way and we were on our way out to the open water.
Did you have any trouble in the open water?
Any patrol boats?
After you get out of the port, it would be international water.
So the patrol, the communist patrol boat,
they don't go out that far.
They would stay around the outer region, and that would be it.
So in other words, we were free.
The only thing that would stop us is weather, and that was one of the main reasons because during that year that they were planning, they also had a plan at what time

when what month they would have they would go because during the July and August season is where the typhoon season and unlucky for us we didn't know that so we chose that month to go and so it took us seven day in the open sea and the four the first
The first day was really calm, but the next four days was just all thunderstorm, typhoon, and all that, the four days.
And we thought that we would not make it because the boat was just going, the wave was just slapping the boat side by side, side by side, and all that.
And in order for us to keep the boat from going over,
from flipping over was a whole bunch of people had to go down to the fishing compartment to stay there so that the balance would be even.
And in other words, in the cabin there would be
Only three men and a couple of kids and my mom would stay in the cabin.
One would navigate, one would steer the boat, and the other would feed the person that steered.
And the kids that are in the cabin would lay down so that you want the boat to be evenly weight so that
you would not have one weight on one side so that it would be so easy to flip over.
So y'all were on rough waters.
Rough water, real.
Once we got out in the open water, everybody was down.
I mean, we were all sick already right there because when, you know, at the part where you go from the port out in the open water, it's really a lot of waves, and...
The boat was shaking already right there, and so we were not used to it yet because I, for one, have not even stepped on a boat before.
So we got sick right there, right away.
So actually, only the last two days were the days that we were really fine.
Otherwise, all the other days, we were gone.
Okay, where did you go from...
from there outside of the port?
I went from the port.
We went all the way to
to the main Thailand.

The main Thailand had little beachfront that so many refugees had escaped that they would just, when their boat was in emergency, like they had a hold, they would just dump their boat right on the shore.
And they would just say, ha, this is where the place we're going to stay.
And so many people did that, that it became a refugee camp.
And so all along the Thailand coast,

shore this all along the thailand mainland were just little camps everywhere that were refugees that were from escape and the majority of them were vietnamese that escaped because we went a year late so by the time we got there by the time that we got to the refuge camp that we stayed it was a really well established had

more more than a hundred people already there you know waiting for them to be sponsored and all that so i went straight into one of these records uh yes we went straight into uh straight into it yeah and what happened there were you processed through or well at that time they the thailand government were really lenient they knew that a lot of people were going to do this so they would accept
all the refugees to come in and for them to live in the camp, you know.
And then we would have to give them paper, tell them what country we prefer to be sponsored to go to and all that.
And then they would give our name to the
one of the ambassadors of that country and he would have a list and every day, every day around
around 10 a.m., there would be guys from other countries, Canada, France, United States, West Germany, and all that.
They would come, and they would read out their list, which one was appropriate for them to go.
And so at that time, every day at 10, everybody would be real crowded in the front gate so that they would hear their name.
And after they hear their name,
they would have to pack and then at the end of the week there would be a bus to come and pick them up.
And usually it would be every other week there would be like around 50 people.
No, no, it would be around 25 people would get picked.
And they would go to the bus and they would get transferred into the capital city of Thailand, which is Bangkok.
And they would stay there for a couple more months for the process of the actual going to whatever country you wanted to go.
How long were y'all in there?
After we stayed in the refugee camps a couple days later, my mom was busy writing letters to my aunt over in Canada.
My aunt in Canada, she lived there for 14 years.
She went to school there, and she got married there, and she decided to stay there.
My mom contacted her for money, and then my mom also contacted a couple of my dad's real good friends that he met while he was over in the United States in 72.
And so she would contact them also to tell them that we are over here already, that we are waiting, and if there's any way they can help us.
you know, please do, and all that.

And so, a couple days later, my aunt would send us money for food and all that, and then one of my dad's friends actually went down to the island, to our place, and he would talk to my mom, and he would say that, you know, don't worry, we're going to get you out of here as soon as possible.
And, uh,
At the end of the month, we were gone.
We were in the list.
You left the refugee camps.
Yes.
So actually, we stayed at the refugee camps only one month.
And after that, we left to Bangkok, and we stayed there.
And the reason why we stayed there three months at the Bangkok place, the reason why we had to stay so long
The reason why we had to stay so long was because we had to do some physical examination and see if you had any disease and a vaccination and all that.
Just take care of yourself and all that.
And the place that we were living in were an abandoned penitentiary.
It was a really big penitentiary.
And when we got there, it was really dirty.
And there were a whole bunch of people that were already there waiting to be picked up.
Everywhere you go, when you got there, you had to go and find yourself a place to live.
So my mom and I, we would go down the court, go down the hall, and check out where we would go.
And there would be these cells that have bar doors.
There would be people actually living in there, and it was really dirty.
They didn't have any bed.
They had to sleep down on the floor.
They provided you mattresses, but no bed frame.
So you actually just put the mattresses on the floor, and you would just sleep there.
And so my mom decided for us not to live in one of those cells, because there would not be air circulating, so that it would be real bad for us.
So what we did was we lived under a staircase.
so that there would be air circulating and all that.
And so we stayed there three months, and then we got on the list.
We had all our physical examination was off.
We're all fine.
So we were accepted to go.
Where were you going to?
We were going to the United States because my mom did not want to go to Canada because, for one thing, it was really cold over there.
So she wanted us to go to the United States.
And also, we had a relative that already left in 1970.
that she was already there.
In fact, she was my dad's oldest sister, and her family were all over there.
She was established in America.
Yeah, she was already established.
So we asked her if she could sponsor us, and she agreed.

you had the main thing is the two main thing is you had to have a sponsor and you have your physical examination have to be good in order for you to be on the list and we didn't waste any time even though three months was was very long but we waited and uh we got on the list a bus came by took us and uh at this time when the whenever the bus come they would pick up a hundred people instead of only 25 because
That place in Bangkok was just packed.
It was just loaded of people.
There were no places to stay.
There were actually people living out in the hall that you can barely walk through it.
And so they would pick up at least 100 people every week.
And those 100 people would go to a certain place that they wanted to go.
So it took us a couple hours to go to the airport.
We got on the plane, and we flew to France.
And we stopped there for fuel, refuel, and then we flew straight to Houston.
And my aunt came and picked us up.
Where does your aunt live?
Where does she live?
My aunt lives in Houston.
So y'all went to live in Houston?
Yes.
We went to live with her for a couple weeks.
And then we finally found... Well, she had a sponsor when she came over.
And so what she did was she asked her sponsor if it was okay if that couple could be our sponsor.
And that couple is a...
old couple, American, an old American couple.
They were really nice and they were really willing and happy to accept us, you know, as sponsor.
And they took care of us.
They brought us clothes, food, and found us an affordable apartment so that we could move out because
My mom wanted us to start out by ourselves, so we only stayed with my aunt for two weeks, and then we were gone.
We went to an apartment that we rented.
So you've lived in Houston ever since?
Yes, we live in Houston ever since.
Okay, what is the status with your father?
He didn't get out after those five years?
Okay, when we got out and when we were still over here and it went past five years and my grandmother quickly contacted us because she knew that my mom would be really
you know, gone berserk.
So she contacted us and she said that there's something wrong, you know, that there seems like they're keeping the officers for a longer time because my uncle, I had one other uncle that was
also went to concentration camp.
And he stayed for only three years.
And he got out.
Was he an officer?
He was a sergeant.
So you had to be a really high commanding officer for you to be staying longer than that.
Also, she said that all the other relatives have sons that were released, but she said that there were no high commanding officers that were released yet.
My mom had a couple of friends that decided to stay back.

instead because they wanted to wait for their husband because their husband because they would said that it would take only five years so that's not long so i'll stay and so uh her friends would come to my grandmother and would cry and would go you know would ask all these questions you know why why is it taking so long and all that how long and now they're gonna they started asking question how long
Are they going to be kept in concentration camp?
Is it going to be forever?
Or when are they going to get released and all that?
And my mom wrote back to my grandmother and said that, OK, we're doing real fine over here.
So just keep going.
just keep me updated on what's going on and all that.
So my grandmother would tell us that everybody is just going berserk.
Everybody's going to their neighbor asking if their husband or their sons have been released yet or did they get any letters from them yet.
And then they would go to the headquarters and complain about it.
They would say that, you know, they wouldn't say that it's five years and how come they're not out, but they would say, you know,
How long are y'all going to plan to keep them and all that?
And so they say that they don't know and all that.
It's up to the head honcho and all that.
Were you in any contact with your father this time?
During that time, the contact was very little.
During that time, we would receive a letter per two months, two months or less.
So in other words, we received only six letters a whole year.
But actually, we did not receive my dad's letter.
My dad mailed it to my grandmother, and my grandmother would go to my aunt, and my aunt would go down to us, my aunt from Canada, because somehow,
I don't know what it is, but somehow the mail seems to circulate faster if you go that way.
Because I have no idea why, but that's how we... At the first time, at the beginning, we did that.
But then later on, we mailed straight from Vietnam all the way down to Houston, which when we opened the letter, we would read, you know,
It was in June, and we would receive it all the way until September.
So it would take around three months for the letter to arrive.
Well, anyway, the wives were getting really crazy.
They were getting worried.

out in the open sea.
